description.short: Measures vulnerability to reduced security vigilance and maintenance behaviors due to depression-induced apathy, cognitive impairment, and systematic degradation of cybersecurity compliance
description.context: Depression-related negligence occurs when work-related stress, burnout, or personal challenges reduce employees' cognitive capacity and motivation to maintain cybersecurity vigilance. This creates systematic vulnerabilities as affected individuals become more susceptible to phishing, neglect password hygiene, delay security updates, and avoid reporting incidents. Organizations with high-stress environments, inadequate mental health support, or blame-focused cultures are particularly vulnerable to this pattern.
description.impact: Organizations experiencing depression-related negligence suffer from increased phishing susceptibility through emotional manipulation attacks, password hygiene degradation through cognitive effort avoidance, delayed incident reporting due to shame and fear, endpoint security degradation through avoidance behaviors, and potential insider threat materialization. Correlations emerge from aggregated incident analysis showing increased security incidents during high-stress periods correlating with reported depression rates, particularly in healthcare sector during pandemic response, financial services correlating with employee assistance program utilization, and technology sector patterns following layoffs and organizational restructuring.
description.psychological_basis: Depression-related negligence emerges from multiple interconnected psychological mechanisms: cognitive dysfunction where depression impairs executive functioning and working memory with reduced dorsolateral prefrontal cortex activation; anhedonia and motivation deficit where loss of interest in activities extends to security protocol compliance; Seligman's learned helplessness model creating generalized expectancies of uncontrollability manifesting as 'why bother?' attitudes toward security measures; and cognitive load amplification where depression reduces available cognitive resources through rumination leaving insufficient mental capacity for security awareness. Neurocognitive studies demonstrate depression disrupts default mode network and executive control networks essential for sustained attention and risk assessment, with anterior cingulate cortex showing reduced activation impairing error monitoring and conflict detection.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Organization has proactive mental health support, stress-aware security policies, non-punitive incident reporting, regular workload assessments, and clear procedures for supporting struggling employees. Security procedures simplified during high-stress periods with automated controls reducing cognitive load.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Organization has some employee support resources but inconsistent implementation, security policies that don't account for stress factors, or mixed responses to security incidents and employee struggles. Basic mental health resources exist but limited integration with security practices.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Organization shows blame-focused incident response, no mental health resources, unrealistic security expectations during stress periods, or punishment-based approaches to security non-compliance. High-pressure environments with chronic overwork and inadequate staffing creating both increased depression risk and reduced capacity for security vigilance.

security_task_completion_degradation.calculation: Percentage increase in time to complete routine security tasks compared to baseline
security_task_completion_degradation.query: SELECT user_id, AVG(completion_time) / baseline_avg FROM security_tasks WHERE time_window='30d' GROUP BY user_id HAVING AVG(completion_time) > 1.5*baseline_avg

incident_reporting_delay.calculation: Time between incident occurrence and reporting submission

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Employee Workload Stress and Work-Life Balance
items.question: How often do employees in security-sensitive roles report being overwhelmed with their workload or express concerns about work-life balance?

options.label: Rarely - Regular workload assessments show manageable stress levels with proactive adjustments during peak periods
Occasionally - Some employees report workload stress but limited systematic monitoring or response
Frequently - Chronic reports of being overwhelmed with no systematic workload assessment or adjustment mechanisms

items.evidence_required: Workload assessment records, recent employee stress example, work-life balance metrics

items.title: Response to Declining Security Performance
items.question: What's your procedure when employees miss security training deadlines, repeatedly fail to update software, or show declining performance in security tasks?

options.label: Supportive intervention to identify and address underlying causes with resources to help employee recover performance
Mixed response - sometimes supportive, sometimes punitive, no consistent approach
Punitive response focused on compliance enforcement without investigating root causes or providing support

items.evidence_required: Response procedure documentation, recent non-compliance handling example

items.title: Security Incident Reporting Culture
items.question: How does your organization respond when someone reports a security incident or near-miss? What happens to the person who reports it?

options.label: Non-punitive learning culture where reporting is protected and celebrated, focus on systemic improvement
Generally neutral response but some fear or hesitation about reporting mistakes
Blame-focused response where individuals fear consequences of reporting security mistakes or incidents

items.evidence_required: Incident reporting policy, recent incident report example, employee reporting comfort assessment

items.title: Mental Health and Stress Management Resources
items.question: What resources does your organization provide to help employees manage work stress, personal challenges, or mental health concerns?

options.label: Comprehensive Employee Assistance Program with confidential counseling, stress management training, and manager awareness programs
Basic resources exist but limited awareness, accessibility, or integration with work practices
No mental health resources or stress management support available to employees

items.evidence_required: EAP documentation, mental health resource descriptions, utilization metrics (aggregated), example of employee using resources
items.soc_mapping: EAP utilization correlation with security performance metrics (aggregated only)

items.title: Behavioral Warning Sign Detection and Response
items.question: How do you monitor and address patterns of increased help desk tickets, delayed responses to security alerts, or employees avoiding complex security procedures?

options.label: Systematic monitoring with supportive interventions when warning patterns detected, focus on helping rather than punishing
Informal awareness but no systematic monitoring or consistent intervention approach
No monitoring of behavioral warning signs or patterns indicating employee distress

items.evidence_required: Monitoring system documentation, warning sign intervention protocol, recent example of detected pattern and response

items.title: Response to Employee Social Withdrawal and Behavioral Changes
items.question: What's your policy for employees who seem isolated, rarely participate in team meetings, or show changes in their usual work patterns?

options.label: Proactive manager check-ins with trained responses, connection to support resources, privacy-protected assistance
Reactive response only when issues become severe or impact work significantly
Behavioral changes ignored unless resulting in formal performance issues or policy violations

items.evidence_required: Manager training materials on recognizing distress, response protocol, recent example of behavioral change management

items.title: Security Expectations During High-Stress Periods
items.question: How often do you assess whether your security procedures are realistic and manageable for employees during high-stress periods or peak workload times?

options.label: Regular assessment with documented adjustments to security requirements during identified stress periods to maintain both security and employee wellbeing
Occasional consideration but no systematic assessment or documented adaptation approach
No assessment or adjustment - same security expectations maintained regardless of workload or stress levels

items.evidence_required: Workload assessment schedule, stress period security adaptations documentation, recent crisis period security approach example
items.soc_mapping: security_task_completion_degradation correlation with known stress periods

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Tell me about a recent instance where workload stress impacted security practices in your organization. What happened and how was it addressed?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific example with proactive identification, supportive intervention, and systematic workload adjustment to restore security compliance
scoring_guidance.yellow: Example shows stress impact recognized but limited intervention or inconsistent response
scoring_guidance.red: Stress impact on security either unrecognized or responded to punitively without addressing root causes

followups.text: How do you identify when workload is becoming unsustainable before security compliance degrades?
What specific adjustments were made to either workload or security requirements during that period?

items.text: Describe your organization's approach during your most recent crisis or busy period. How did security expectations and support change?

scoring_guidance.green: Documented stress-aware security design with automated controls, simplified procedures, and enhanced support during crisis periods
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some informal recognition of stress impact but no systematic adaptation of security requirements
scoring_guidance.red: Same rigid security expectations maintained during crisis periods with no accommodation for stress impact

followups.text: Did security incident rates change during this high-stress period? What patterns did you observe?
What would you do differently in the next crisis period based on this experience?

items.text: Walk me through the last time someone reported clicking a suspicious link or making a security mistake. What exactly happened to them?

scoring_guidance.green: Non-punitive response with immediate support, systemic analysis, protection for reporter, and organizational learning focus
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed response with some support but also elements of blame or consequences for the individual
scoring_guidance.red: Punitive response, blame focus, or example shows employees avoid reporting mistakes due to fear of consequences

followups.text: How long did it take from when the person realized the mistake to when they reported it? What influenced that timing?
What specific policies protect employees who report security mistakes from retaliation or punishment?

subsections.title: Employee Support and Mental Health Integration

items.text: Give me a specific instance where an employee used your mental health or stress management resources. How was it handled and integrated with their work?

scoring_guidance.green: Confidential, well-supported example with seamless integration, no negative consequences, and positive outcomes for both employee and security performance
scoring_guidance.yellow: Resources exist and used but unclear confidentiality, limited integration, or mixed outcomes
scoring_guidance.red: No examples of resource usage, employees fear using resources, or stigma prevents utilization

followups.text: How do managers know when to suggest these resources without violating privacy or creating stigma?
What prevents employees from using these resources? What have you done to address those barriers?

items.text: Tell me about a time when you noticed warning signs like increased help desk tickets, delayed security responses, or employee withdrawal. What action did you take?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic detection with supportive, privacy-protected intervention focused on understanding and addressing root causes
scoring_guidance.yellow: Warning signs noticed informally but inconsistent or delayed intervention
scoring_guidance.red: Warning signs either not noticed, ignored, or responded to punitively without investigating underlying issues

followups.text: What specific metrics or indicators do you track to identify employees who may be struggling before security failures occur?
How do you balance privacy concerns with proactive support for employees showing distress indicators?

items.text: Share how you recently handled an employee who was consistently non-compliant with security procedures. What was your approach?

scoring_guidance.green: Investigative approach seeking to understand root causes, supportive interventions, resources provided, focus on enabling compliance rather than punishment
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mix of investigation and enforcement but unclear or inconsistent approach
scoring_guidance.red: Purely enforcement-focused response with progressive discipline and no investigation of underlying causes

followups.text: What did you learn about why the non-compliance was happening? Were there workload, stress, or capability factors involved?
What was the outcome for both the employee and the organization's security posture?

solutions.title: Stress-Aware Security Design
solutions.description: Simplify security procedures during high-stress periods, implement automated security controls to reduce human decision points, create emergency mode security protocols
solutions.implementation: Identify high-stress periods through workload analytics and organizational calendar (quarter-end, seasonal peaks, crisis events). Design simplified security workflows that maintain protection while reducing cognitive load. Implement automated patch management, password managers with enterprise support, single sign-on solutions, and security dashboards reducing decision complexity. Create clearly documented emergency mode protocols that adjust security expectations during identified stress periods while maintaining critical protections through automation and simplified procedures.
solutions.technical_controls: Automated patch management, password manager deployment, SSO implementation, cognitive load reduction technology, stress-period security workflow automation

solutions.title: Anonymous Incident Reporting System
solutions.description: Deploy confidential reporting mechanisms separating incident response from disciplinary action, focus on learning rather than blame
solutions.implementation: Implement anonymous or confidential incident reporting channels that separate immediate security response from any individual accountability discussions. Create explicit policies that incident reporting is protected behavior and will not result in negative consequences for good-faith reports. Design response procedures focusing on systemic improvements rather than individual blame. Provide immediate support for employees who report security mistakes, including access to technical assistance and stress management resources. Train incident response teams on non-punitive investigation approaches and psychological safety principles.
solutions.technical_controls: Anonymous reporting portal, incident response workflow with protection flags, employee support integration, reporting analytics dashboard

solutions.title: Employee Assistance Program Integration
solutions.description: Establish partnerships with mental health professionals, provide confidential counseling services, train managers to recognize warning signs
solutions.implementation: Deploy comprehensive EAP with confidential access to mental health professionals specializing in workplace stress, depression, and anxiety. Create manager training programs on recognizing behavioral warning signs without violating privacy, with clear protocols for supportive referrals to resources. Ensure absolute confidentiality and protection from employment consequences for seeking mental health support. Integrate stress management training into security awareness programs. Develop peer support networks for security-related stress with trained facilitators and professional supervision.
solutions.technical_controls: EAP platform with confidential access, manager training management system, peer support coordination tools, utilization analytics (aggregated only)

solutions.title: Workload and Security Balance Monitoring
solutions.description: Implement regular assessments of whether security expectations are realistic given current workloads, adjust requirements during peak stress periods
solutions.implementation: Establish quarterly workload assessment processes evaluating whether security requirements are achievable given current staffing and business demands. Use analytics to identify employees showing stress-related security pattern changes including increased help desk tickets, delayed task completion, training deadline misses, or communication pattern changes. Create documented procedures for adjusting security expectations during identified high-stress periods while maintaining critical protections through automation. Implement early warning systems that flag behavioral indicators before security failures occur, triggering supportive interventions rather than punitive responses.
solutions.technical_controls: Workload analytics platform, behavioral pattern detection algorithms, security compliance monitoring with stress correlation, early warning dashboard

solutions.title: Peer Support Network Development
solutions.description: Create confidential peer support groups for security-related stress, establish buddy systems for security accountability, develop mental health first aid training
solutions.implementation: Establish peer support programs specifically addressing security work stress, including regular check-ins, confidential discussion groups, and buddy systems for mutual security accountability and emotional support. Train security team leaders and senior personnel in mental health first aid to recognize depression indicators and provide appropriate initial support and referrals. Create communities of practice around security challenges that normalize discussion of stress impacts and provide collective problem-solving. Ensure peer programs maintain professional boundaries and confidentiality with oversight from mental health professionals.
solutions.technical_controls: Peer support coordination platform, mental health first aid training system, community of practice collaboration tools, confidentiality management

solutions.title: Cognitive Load Reduction Technology
solutions.description: Deploy password managers with enterprise support, implement single sign-on solutions, use automated patch management, create security dashboards reducing decision complexity
solutions.implementation: Systematically reduce security-related cognitive burden through technology deployment. Implement enterprise password managers eliminating need to remember multiple complex passwords. Deploy comprehensive single sign-on reducing authentication friction. Automate patch management removing manual update decisions. Create unified security dashboards presenting only actionable information with clear next steps. Design all security tools with user experience focus minimizing cognitive load especially important for users under stress. Measure security tool usability and continuously improve based on user feedback particularly from high-stress periods.
solutions.technical_controls: Enterprise password manager, SSO platform, automated patch management system, unified security dashboard, security tool UX optimization

risk_scenarios.title: Phishing Campaign Success Through Emotional Manipulation
risk_scenarios.description: Stressed employees become prime targets for emotional manipulation phishing attacks that promise relief, support, or solutions to work problems. Attackers profile organizations during known high-stress periods and craft messages exploiting depression-related vulnerabilities.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Phishing emails with emotional manipulation targeting depression indicators - offering mental health resources, schedule relief, problem-solving assistance, or validation
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Depression-induced cognitive dysfunction impairs threat detection while anhedonia and motivation deficit reduce scrutiny of suspicious communications. Emotional manipulation promises relief from overwhelming stress.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Healthcare organization during COVID-19 experienced multiple successful phishing attacks when overwhelmed staff clicked links promising 'mental health resources' or 'schedule relief' during peak pandemic stress

risk_scenarios.title: Password Security Collapse During Stress Periods
risk_scenarios.description: Depression-affected employees revert to simple passwords, share credentials to avoid MFA fatigue, or write passwords insecurely due to cognitive overload and reduced concern for future consequences
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Credential stuffing and password spraying attacks targeting organizations during identified high-stress periods when password hygiene degrades
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Cognitive effort avoidance leads to password reuse and weak passwords. Temporal discounting reduces concern for future security consequences. Difficulty maintaining complex requirements under cognitive load.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Financial services company discovered widespread password reuse after major layoff period when remaining employees couldn't manage complex security requirements under increased workload stress

risk_scenarios.title: Delayed Incident Reporting Allowing Breach Expansion
risk_scenarios.description: Employees avoid reporting security mistakes due to fear, shame, or belief that nothing will improve, allowing minor incidents to escalate into major breaches while compromised systems remain active
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Attackers exploit extended dwell time when victims delay reporting initial compromise due to depression-related shame and learned helplessness
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Shame amplification and self-blame prevent reporting. Fear of additional stress and scrutiny. Learned helplessness reduces belief in effectiveness of reporting. Catastrophic thinking about consequences.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Technology company's data breach expanded for weeks because initial victim was afraid to report clicking malicious link during high-stress product launch, allowing attackers extended access to compromised systems

risk_scenarios.title: Insider Threat Escalation Through Depression and Organizational Stress
risk_scenarios.description: Severe depression combined with organizational stress can lead to intentional security violations, data theft, or sabotage by employees who feel hopeless or betrayed by their employer
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Insider data exfiltration or sabotage by depressed employees with reduced organizational loyalty and increased risk tolerance
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Depression reduces loyalty and organizational commitment. Increased susceptibility to external recruitment. Higher tolerance for rule-breaking behaviors. Potential for intentional sabotage during severe episodes.
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Patterns in insider threat cases show correlation between employee assistance program utilization spikes, organizational restructuring periods, and increased insider security incidents
